instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on. Only 5.25v on both USBC ports. <SIGNAL>PP1V1_S3</SIGNAL> only 2.3立
threads.message:
Hi all.
Looking at a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that was extensively water damaged.
After cleaning, I'm only getting 5v on both USBC ports.

With the AC adaptor connected to the primary (REAR) USBC port: 
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_T_VBUS</SIGNAL> 0.00v
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_X_VBUS</SIGNAL> 5.25v
However,
With the AC adaptor connected to the secondary (FRONT) USBC port: 
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_T_VBUS</SIGNAL> 5.25v
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_X_VBUS</SIGNAL> constantly fluctuating/cycling between 0.00v and about 0.50v

I would normally assume that the fluctuating voltage would indicate a short on <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_X_VBUS</SIGNAL>, however as it shows 5.25v on the other port, it cannot be shorted.
Would this indicate a problem with the Secondary USBC controller?

I also just noticed that <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> also fluctuates from about 2.98v to 5.05v ONLY when connected to the secondary USBC port.

Checking coils, <SIGNAL>PP1V1_S3</SIGNAL> also seems to be too low. 
In diode mode, red to ground, it measures 008.
In resistance mode it measures 2.3立 to ground.

Any suggestions appreciated, thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on. Only 5.25v on both USBC ports. <SIGNAL>PP1V1_S3</SIGNAL> only 2.3立
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>1V1_S3</SIGNAL> powers up the RAM and CPU.
CPU is the most sensitive there; probably dead now.

You have a problem on USB-C area too.
Anyway, not worth to spend time there, with dead CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on. Only 5.25v on both USBC ports. <SIGNAL>PP1V1_S3</SIGNAL> only 2.3立
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 101935, member: 682"]
<SIGNAL>1V1_S3</SIGNAL> powers up the RAM and CPU.
CPU is the most sensitive there; probably dead now.

You have a problem on USB-C area too.
Anyway, not worth to spend time there, with dead CPU.
[/QUOTE]
Thanks once again 2informaticos, I appreciate your advice.
